AVSEC ORDER NO.   04  / 2010 
 
 
Sub:   Issuance of Temporary Airport Entry Passes by the Airport 
Operators under Rule-90(1), Rule 90(3) and Rule 90 (4) of 
Aircraft Rules 1937. 
 
Commissioner of Security (Civil Aviation), Bureau of Civil Aviation 
Security, in exercise of powers conferred by Section 5A of Aircraft Act 1934 
delegated to him vide Government of India, Ministry of Civil Aviation 
Notification No. 1797 dated July 3, 1997 read with Rule 90 of Aircraft Rules 
1937 hereby directs that:  
 
 
i. No Permanent AEPs shall  be issued by Airport Operators. Only 
Temporary Airport Entry Passes  (AEPs) for Indian Nationals, for a 
period of maximum of 30 days, in a period of six months, can be 
issued by the Airport Operators for their own airport only. 
Background check/verification of the applicant from the Police 
Station concerned, is required for issuance of Airport Entry Passes 
for a period of 4 days & above. In case of foreigners, appropriate 
temporary pass will be issued only after approval from BCAS. 
 
 
ii. Only Indian national (Not Foreign National) shall be authorised for 
issuing Temporary AEPs. 
 
iii. No renewal/extension of these Temporary AEPs will be done by the 
Airport Operators. Any such renewal/ extension of temporary AEPs 
by the Airport Operators, beyond 30 days, will be treated as illegal. 
In case there is any further requirement, the same may be 
forwarded to concerned Regional office of BCAS. The pass may be 
issued by the operator for the entire duration of work/contract  after 
getting approval of the same from concerned RDCOS,BCAS. 
 
iv. In-charge APSU/CASO shall not be involved in the process of 
issuance of temp. AEPs in any manner whatsoever;

v. The Commissioner of Security (CA); and his officer authorised by 
him shall continue to issue AEPs/Temp. AEPs; and  
 
vi. Specimen signature of the issuing authority of temp. AEPs shall be 
sent to CASO/in-charge APSU. 
 
The above directions shall be implemented by all airport operators in the 
country with immediate effect. Violations, if any, shall attract legal action under 
Section 11A of Aircraft Act 1934. 
 
 
 
(M.Malaviya)

Addl. Commissioner of Security (CA)
